 Your explanation on "phobias" is incomplete. When used as a suffix, -phobia has two meanings...
 
 Main Entry: -phobia
 Function: noun combining form
 Etymology: New Latin, from Late Latin, from Greek, from -phobos fearing, from phobos fear, flight, from phebesthai to flee; akin to Lithuanian begti to flee, Old Church Slavic bezati
 1 : exaggerated fear of <acrophobia<
 2 : intolerance or aversion for <photophobia< 
 http://www.m-w.com/dictionary/-phobia
 
 Look up the word "xenophobia" and you'll see something similar. 
 xenophobia: fear and hatred of strangers or foreigners or of anything that is strange or foreign

 You are missinformed by what constitutes sexual harassment.
 
 http://www.eeoc.gov/types/sexual_harassment.html
 
 
Unwelcome sexual advances, requests for sexual favors, and other verbal or physical conduct of a sexual nature constitute sexual harassment when this conduct explicitly or implicitly affects an individual's employment, unreasonably interferes with an individual's work performance, or creates an intimidating, hostile, or offensive work environment.
 
 Sexual harassment can occur in a variety of circumstances, including but not limited to the following:
 The victim as well as the harasser may be a woman or a man. The victim does not have to be of the opposite sex.
 The harasser can be the victim's supervisor, an agent of the employer, a supervisor in another area, a co-worker, or a non-employee.
 The victim does not have to be the person harassed but could be anyone affected by the offensive conduct.
 Unlawful sexual harassment may occur without economic injury to or discharge of the victim.
 The harasser's conduct must be unwelcome.

Do you really not see the counter-productiveness of such things, as well as the contradiction in saying "we just want to be left alone"? I've long gotten the impression from your posts that you think the gay pride movement is above reproach on all things, but let's be realistic. Now it's true that such things happen in other non-gay-related events too (such as Mardi Gras) but these events aren't associated with any cultural/political pride movement either. 
 
 
It's unfortunate you don't happen to like that, but none the less it's true.

 
 Please don't subscribe views to me that I haven't expressed nor do I hold to. I certainly believe gays should have social cultural acceptance to the extent everyone else has. Persecution and prejudice are wrong, no matter who the targets are--gays included.
 
 
Yet what is wrong with that? Every other culture can have its thing but not gay culture? The catholics of mexico and south and central america can drag a statue and parts of dead bodies though the streets throwing flowers at at it yet that is not considered weird. I bet you would not think that native americans marching half naked though the streets.

 
 
Let's not forget mardi gras ... [tv shows] ...

 
 But these events are not a group doing anything for the sake of pride. These aren't being done to achieve social acceptance like the pride parades are. If people want to be nude, that's their business. But for heaven's sake, don't expect people to look at that and say "oh, we need to be socially accepting!" Or expect it to make people want to just "leave you alone"!
Kronus

So then why have pride events like parades had the over-the-top focus on sexual behavior? 

 They don't. But gay pride parades do tend to be inclusive, rather than exclusive. You've never actually been to one, have you? I have, and for every float with chaps clad muscle men you'll have 10 that are just average people who happen to be gay. Most of the participants are pushing the "look, I'm just like you" message. A few are pushing the "it's my life and I won't be ashamed of it" message. The parade organizers aren't there to censor anyone or push their own agenda, they'll pretty much let in anyone who wants to march. Of course it's only the half naked men that make it into the paper, and that's unfortunate, because then people get the mistaken impression that the marches are all about sex. Before you condemn them you might want to try actually watching one.
 
 

 Please don't subscribe views to me that I haven't expressed nor do I hold to. I certainly believe gays should have social cultural acceptance to the extent everyone else has. Persecution and prejudice are wrong, no matter who the targets are--gays included.

 
 What you said:
 "See, I'd have less of a problem with the gay pride movement if it had been limited to it's legal battles, but it hasn't."
 What I said:
 "Of course the gay rights movement isn't just about legislation, it's also about social acceptance. It's unfortunate you don't happen to like that, but none the less it's true."
 
 Seems to me I addressed exactly what you said. If you didn't mean what you said, if you meant to express your views differently, you really can't blame me for that. But what you said was that you'd prefer that gays stick to just trying to change laws.
samiinh

I believe that Gay Pride began as a way to tell the world that gay people have the same right as anyone else to be proud of who they are. Until the late 1960s, gay people were forced to hide in the "closets" of their lives. The closet is not a very happy place to be. But unless you'd lived that , you'd have no idea why it is like. 
 
 I don't personally enjoy "over the top" displays that one might witness in a pride parade, nor would I enjoy that type of display on a marti gras float either. But I understand where it comes from. If you don't like it, don't watch. Simple.
jitobear

Jito, I'm not trying to speak for all heteros. But, the opinions I've heard mostly lean toward hostility toward advances by homos. And, I would be sick to my stomach over it. Why would you be embarrassed by that?

 
 
 Hostility due to a compliment? I really have to explain this to you?
Kronus

Hostility due to a compliment? I really have to explain this to you?

 
 I've really never understood this. I've had several gay men hit on me, and I was flattered. I politely said no, and they went away, no big deal. I really don't get why anyone would get upset over the idea that someone else finds them attractive. 
 
 Well, ok, I do get it, sorta. If a gay man thinks you're cute, people might think you're gay, and if you don't get mad then that proves you're gay. And there's nothing worse than being gay, or having people think you're gay, so if a gay guy hits on you you better be sure to react strongly and negatively, or else you might catch the ghey. Or something like that. :xbanghead
ShadowPikachu

So then why have pride events like parades had the over-the-top focus on sexual behavior? Is associating nudity and 'grinding' with the pride movement (by having it in parades) necessary to get social acceptance, and avoid persecution, in your view? Do you really not see the counter-productiveness of such things, as well as the contradiction in saying "we just want to be left alone"? I've long gotten the impression from your posts that you think the gay pride movement is above reproach on all things, but let's be realistic. Now it's true that such things happen in other non-gay-related events too (such as Mardi Gras) but these events aren't associated with any cultural/political pride movement either. 
 

 
 What gay pride parade were you at!? emoticon_wow All of the ones I've gone to (quite a few in fact) are pretty much the opposite of your stereotyping statement. Perhaps you could show us all of the parades in which such behaviour is going on? Every Gay pride parade I've gone to are like a funeral march compared to some of the Mardi Gras parades I've gone to or seen.
ShadowPikachu

I've really never understood this. I've had several gay men hit on me, and I was flattered. I politely said no, and they went away, no big deal. I really don't get why anyone would get upset over the idea that someone else finds them attractive. 
 
 Well, ok, I do get it, sorta. If a gay man thinks you're cute, people might think you're gay, and if you don't get mad then that proves you're gay. And there's nothing worse than being gay, or having people think you're gay, so if a gay guy hits on you you better be sure to react strongly and negatively, or else you might catch the ghey. Or something like that. :xbanghead

 
 I do not get it either. Just tell them you don't swing that way, and for the most part, they realize that "no" means "no". You might run into one or two pushy people, but I've definitely run into many more push a-hole heteros trying to hit on me after I tell them I'm not interested than I have Lesbians doing the same (in fact, that has never happened with a lesbian I've met).
 
 I certainly have had a few lesbians hit on me, and I take it as a compliment that they think I'm attractive enough for them to take an interest in me. I just tell them I'm not interested, or that I actually have a fiance at the moment, and they take it at that - in fact, that's how I met one of my best friends who is a lesbian: she hit on me, I told her that, and then we started chatting it up, and eventually became close friends.
 
 I really don't get why people would take it as an insult or something.
jyoshu

They don't. But gay pride parades do tend to be inclusive, rather than exclusive. You've never actually been to one, have you? I have, and for every float with chaps clad muscle men you'll have 10 that are just average people who happen to be gay.

 
 You just contradicted yourself. On one hand you say they don't have those things, and then two sentences later you basically assert that 10% of them are that way (even though that wasn't your intention). Even one would be over-the-top.
 
 
A few are pushing the "it's my life and I won't be ashamed of it" message.

 
 Heh, well that's one way to put it. emoticon_xgood 
 
 
The parade organizers aren't there to censor anyone or push their own agenda, they'll pretty much let in anyone who wants to march. Of course it's only the half naked men that make it into the paper, and that's unfortunate

 
 Well of course they make it into the paper. When people are doing that in plain sight in front of kids or whoever, it's naturally going to make the news. And I don't see why parade organizers wouldn't want to be selective in who they let march. But hey, it's their parade, and their movement. If they want to give everyone the wrong impression, whatever.
 
 
What you said:
 "See, I'd have less of a problem with the gay pride movement if it had been limited to it's legal battles, but it hasn't."

 
 And so I said nothing to the effect of having a problem with them wanting social acceptance. You're jumping to conclusions. You used the 'social acceptance' comment in response to my comment about the lewdness in parades (which, of course, isn't necessary for the social acceptance of gays. If anything, lewdness is going to turn a lot of people off).
jyoshu

I don't personally enjoy "over the top" displays that one might witness in a pride parade, nor would I enjoy that type of display on a marti gras float either. But I understand where it comes from. If you don't like it, don't watch. Simple.

 
 I respect that answer, actually. It's very honest.
ShadowPikachu

Well of course they make it into the paper. When people are doing that in plain sight in front of kids or whoever, it's naturally going to make the news. And I don't see why parade organizers wouldn't want to be selective in who they let march. But hey, it's their parade, and their movement. If they want to give everyone the wrong impression, whatever.
 
 
 
 And so I said nothing to the effect of having a problem with them wanting social acceptance. You're jumping to conclusions. You used the 'social acceptance' comment in response to my comment about the lewdness in parades (which, of course, isn't necessary for the social acceptance of gays. If anything, lewdness is going to turn a lot of people off).

 Again, what parades have you been to, Jyosu. Which ones are having all of this "lewdness" that you are talking about? Every one I've been to is completely opposite the way you described it as.
jyoshu

Again, what parades have you been to, Jyosu. Which ones are having all of this "lewdness" that you are talking about? Every one I've been to is completely opposite the way you described it as.

 
 So you've never seen anything that you'd consider lewd in one of these parades? I haven't been to one, and I'm basing this on news reports I've read. I may try to sometime (without my children!) just to see if everything I've heard about them is correct or not. I'm willing to question it based on what you're saying here, but I find it hard to believe that so many people would be wrong.
Matthew S

So you've never seen anything that you'd consider lewd in one of these parades? I haven't been to one, and I'm basing this on news reports I've read. I may try to sometime (without my children!) just to see if everything I've heard about them is correct or not. I'm willing to question it based on what you're saying here, but I find it hard to believe that so many people would be wrong.

 
 I don't consider any sexual activity or displayes between consenting public or private to be either lewed or immoral
samiinh

About three years ago I went to the Boston Gay Pride Parade. It was a very larger parade and lasted several hours. There were a number of floats with all kinds of people on board. There were some with draq queens all decked out in their finest attire; there were politicans; there were families; there were church groups. Everyone was having a grand time. I saw nothing lewd; over the top perhaps, but nothing lewd.
ShadowPikachu

So you've never seen anything that you'd consider lewd in one of these parades? I haven't been to one, and I'm basing this on news reports I've read. I may try to sometime (without my children!) just to see if everything I've heard about them is correct or not. I'm willing to question it based on what you're saying here, but I find it hard to believe that so many people would be wrong.

 
 Every parade that I have been to, I have seen nothing that I'd consider lewd whatsoever. You might glimpse a gay couple kissing in the "audience" (among the spectators, or maybe once or twice within the parade), but not like "sucking-each-other's-faces-off" kind of kissing like I see everyday in parks and restaurants with heteros, or even any more than what you might see in a, I don't know, Thanksgiving day parade between hetero couples. 
 
 If you consider a man kissing another man on the lips to be lewd, well then I wouldn't recommend going, but otherwise, nothing out of the ordinary. If I had children I would have absolutely have no problem bringing them to the parade, and when I do eventually have a kid or two, I will. Mardi gras, however, would be something I consider "lewd", just to give you an idea of my views - anything beyond seeing someone kissing someone else in an event such as a parade would be lewd to me. You should check it out sometime if they have a big parade near you - it's a great chance to meet nice people, and even make some friends.
 
 I personally have NEVER heard of the "lewdness" you have been told of, except by some "Christian" organizations making claims, but I take everything they have to say about gays with a pillar of salt. (Just had'ta het that Bible pun in there) ;)
samiinh
Actually, I've seen more lewd behavior in the check out lanes at Walmart than I ever saw at a gpp. Now, on the gay beach in Provincetown....well, that's another story.
Kronus

You just contradicted yourself. On one hand you say they don't have those things, and then two sentences later you basically assert that 10% of them are that way (even though that wasn't your intention). Even one would be over-the-top.
 

 What you said:
 "parades had the over-the-top focus on sexual behavior?"
 In point of fact I contradicted your concept of over-the-top focus, not myself. If you think 10% of the people wearing chaps is a focus on sex then that's your special definition, but I don't share it.
 
 

 Well of course they make it into the paper. When people are doing that in plain sight in front of kids or whoever, it's naturally going to make the news.

 Doing "that". What is it you think they're doing, anyway? You do realize that these parades have to follow all local decency laws, don't you? Some people may be in leather or scantily clad, but it's not like their naked or having sex or anything. You really haven't ever actually seen one of these, have you? You're not basing this on anything other than what you've been fed, am I right?
 
 

 And I don't see why parade organizers wouldn't want to be selective in who they let march. But hey, it's their parade, and their movement. If they want to give everyone the wrong impression, whatever.

 I think it's more a case of those who want the wrong impression are going to get it anyway. 1 in 10, 1 in 100, or one guy in the crowd. If that picture was the one that made it into the papers, those who were looking for a reason to disapprove would have it. And as for being selective, the movement is about equality and acceptance. Being exclusive would be a bit contradictory, don't you think? 
 
 

 And so I said nothing to the effect of having a problem with them wanting social acceptance. You're jumping to conclusions.

 I'm reading what you wrote and drawing conclusions from that, yes. Again, what you said is "See, I'd have less of a problem with the gay pride movement if it had been limited to it's legal battles, but it hasn't." Sticking to legal battles means not working on social acceptance, seeing as how they're different things and all. That is what you said. If it's not what you meant then just say you misspoke and move on, but cut out the spin.
ShadowPikachu

To add to my last post, Jyoshu, if you are anywhere near Denver, they have an excellent one - I've gone the last five or so years. I've also been to several in Florida while visiting relatives; one in Madison, Wisconsin while visiting my fiance's folks; and consistently over the years I've driven the three hours or so from Kansas City (where I live as do my folks) to St. Louis, Missouri for their parade. I think you are probably better of either believing people who have actually been there, or going to see for yourself.
jyoshu

I think you are probably better of either believing people who have actually been there, or going to see for yourself.

 
 That sounds reasonable. I'll keep it in mind.
gman

Maybe you should meet some to learn that we are not much different than you are. Then, maybe you'd understand that all we want is to be left alone but treated equally by the civil government.

 
 You seem to have come to the conclusion that I have ill feelings toward homosexuals. I do not. I wish no grief on them. I, as you, want only to be left alone without being coerced to be politically correct. 
 What exactly is it that civil government owes you? And why? 
 Are the demands, rights? Or benefits?
samiinh

You seem to have come to the conclusion that I have ill feelings toward homosexuals. I do not. I wish no grief on them. I, as you, want only to be left alone without being coerced to be politically correct. 
 What exactly is it that civil government owes you? And why? 
 Are the demands, rights? Or benefits?

 
 
 What I believe the civil government needs to do is recognize the relationships of gay people and provide those relationships and their families with the same civil rights that it provides for other relationships and families. Nothing more, nothing less. I personally don't care what you call it, but I do believe it should be the same for all couples. (I do not include in that, people who are connected by blood). I don't understand what is so difficult about this.
jitobear

Sure some gay people may behave lewdly in public, so do some straights. Pointing an accusing finger at all gays or the gay rights movement due to the lewd behavior of some would be like pointing an accusing finger at all straights based on the bahavior of Ana Nicole.
jyoshu

Sure some gay people may behave lewdly in public, so do some straights. Pointing an accusing finger at all gays or the gay rights movement due to the lewd behavior of some would be like pointing an accusing finger at all straights based on the bahavior of Ana Nicole.

 
 But Ana Nicole or Mardi Gras or any of these examples weren't being done for the sake of a pride movement.

How many straight people need to learn to feel good about themselves because of their sexual orientation? emoticon_confused

 I would have to agree.
 For me, lewd is anything beyond holding hands, hugging and general peck type of kissing. Regardless of sexual orientation. I'm more offended by behaviors of teenage heteros in the local mall that I have been of any overt gay couple I've witnessed.
 
 Any rel difference between a gay parade and a St. Patricks one? Gay people more of a problem than say those perpetually drunk, violent catholics? (my wife's Irish, I took her name, so I'm 'Irish', my kids are 'Irish'...I should never have hooked them up with the Whisky when they were teething.)
 
 I've worn drag in public before. ~1994-5 Walked around the red-neck part of town. Went to a gay bar with my heterosexual wife. I'm not gay nor a transvestite, just something I did on a lark. Haven't done it since.
 Does that make me lewd? Would I have to be in a parade supporting those who believe they are more comfortable engaging in the behavior I did on a lark make me lewd?
 The only problems I had was not knowing which bathroom to go into at a McDonalds...and buying pump shoes my size.
